verses.text: After these things, Naboth the Jezreelite had a vineyard in Jezreel, beside the palace of Ahab king of Samaria.
verses.comment: Names and places kept consistent with original Hebrew.

verses.text: Ahab spoke to Naboth, saying, 'Give me your vineyard, so that I may have it for a vegetable garden, because it is close beside my house. I will give you a better vineyard in its place, or, if it seems good to you, I will give you its value in money.'
verses.comment: Literal sense maintained: 'give me', 'vegetable garden' (original Hebrew 'garden of herbs').

verses.text: But Naboth said to Ahab, 'May the LORD forbid that I should give you the inheritance of my fathers.'
verses.comment: Phrase 'May the LORD forbid' reflects Hebrew idiom for strong refusal by appeal to God.

verses.text: So Ahab went into his house sullen and angry because of what Naboth the Jezreelite had said to him, for he said, 'I will not give you the inheritance of my fathers.' He lay down on his bed, turned his face away, and would not eat.
verses.comment: Modern equivalents: 'sullen and angry' for Hebrew idiom ('vexed and angry'), 'turned his face away' kept literal.

verses.text: Jezebel his wife came to him and asked, 'Why are you so upset that you are not eating?'
verses.comment: Question modernized for clarity.

verses.text: He answered her, 'Because I spoke to Naboth the Jezreelite and said to him, “Sell me your vineyard for money, or, if you prefer, I will give you another vineyard in its place.” But he said, “I will not give you my vineyard.”'
verses.comment: Quoted speech presented clearly.

verses.text: Jezebel his wife said to him, 'Do you now exercise authority over Israel? Get up, eat, and let your heart be cheerful. I will give you the vineyard of Naboth the Jezreelite.'
verses.comment: Her rhetorical rebuke follows idiomatic translation.

verses.text: So she wrote letters in Ahab’s name, sealed them with his seal, and sent the letters to the elders and nobles who lived in Naboth’s city, who dwelt with him.
verses.comment: Actions and official protocols preserved.

verses.text: She wrote in the letters, saying, 'Proclaim a fast and put Naboth at the head of the people.'
verses.comment: 'Proclaim a fast' for corporate solemn event. 'at the head' meaning 'chief seat.'

verses.text: 'Set two men, sons of Belial, opposite him, and let them bear witness against him, saying, “You cursed God and the king.” Then take him out and stone him to death.'
verses.comment: 'sons of Belial' kept literal (i.e., worthless men), not paraphrased.

verses.text: The men of his city, the elders and nobles who lived in his city, did as Jezebel had sent word to them, as it was written in the letters which she had sent to them.
verses.comment: Direct action completed, no embellishments.

verses.text: They proclaimed a fast and set Naboth at the head of the people.
verses.comment: Short statement, matches Hebrew syntax.

verses.text: Then the two men, sons of Belial, came in and sat in front of him. The worthless men testified against Naboth before the people, saying, 'Naboth cursed God and the king.' So they took him outside the city and stoned him to death.
verses.comment: 'sons of Belial' clarified as 'worthless men' in narration.

verses.text: Then they sent word to Jezebel, saying, 'Naboth has been stoned; he is dead.'
verses.comment: Plain, direct speech.

verses.text: When Jezebel heard that Naboth had been stoned and was dead, Jezebel said to Ahab, 'Arise, take possession of the vineyard of Naboth the Jezreelite, which he refused to sell you; for Naboth is not alive, but dead.'
verses.comment: Jezebel’s directive kept as commanding statement.

verses.text: So when Ahab heard that Naboth was dead, he got up to go down to the vineyard of Naboth the Jezreelite and take possession of it.
verses.comment: Action statement: 'got up to go down' consistent with Hebrew verb forms.

verses.text: Then the word of the LORD came to Elijah the Tishbite, saying,
verses.comment: Hebrew form 'word of the LORD came' kept literal.

verses.text: 'Arise, go down to meet Ahab king of Israel, who is in Samaria. Behold, he is in the vineyard of Naboth, where he has gone to take possession.'
verses.comment: Imperative 'arise, go' and location addressed plainly.

verses.text: 'Say to him, “Thus says the LORD: Have you killed and also taken possession?” And you shall say to him, “In the place where dogs licked the blood of Naboth, dogs will lick your own blood—even yours.”'
verses.comment: 'Have you killed and also taken possession?' matches Hebrew parallel wording. 'even yours' retained for emphasis.

verses.text: Ahab said to Elijah, 'Have you found me, O my enemy?' He answered, 'I have found you, because you have sold yourself to do what is evil in the sight of the LORD.'
verses.comment: Speech direct. 'sold yourself' kept as in original.

verses.text: 'Behold, I will bring disaster upon you. I will consume your descendants, and will cut off from Ahab every male, both bond and free in Israel.'
verses.comment: 'every male, both bond and free' matches Hebrew idiom ('one who urinates against the wall').

verses.text: 'I will make your house like the house of Jeroboam son of Nebat, and like the house of Baasha son of Ahijah, for the anger by which you have provoked Me, and caused Israel to sin.'
verses.comment: References to previous kings kept as in original.

verses.text: And of Jezebel the LORD also spoke, saying, 'The dogs will eat Jezebel by the rampart of Jezreel.'
verses.comment: 'By the rampart' translates Hebrew 'by the wall'; site specific as in original.

verses.text: 'The one belonging to Ahab who dies in the city the dogs will eat, and the one who dies in the field the birds of the heavens will eat.'
verses.comment: Judgment formula kept as in original narrative.

verses.text: Surely there was no one like Ahab who sold himself to do evil in the sight of the LORD, urged on by Jezebel his wife.
verses.comment: Summary of Ahab’s unique wickedness kept literal.

verses.text: He acted in a most abominable way by going after idols, just as the Amorites had done, whom the LORD cast out before the Israelites.
verses.comment: 'Acted abominably' kept literal; Amorite reference as per Hebrew.

verses.text: When Ahab heard these words, he tore his clothes, put sackcloth on his body, and fasted. He lay in sackcloth and went about humbly.
verses.comment: Ahab’s actions: 'lay in sackcloth, went about humbly' per Hebrew verbs.

verses.text: Then the word of the LORD came to Elijah the Tishbite, saying,
verses.comment: Matches Hebrew phrasing for prophetic address.

verses.text: 'Have you seen how Ahab has humbled himself before Me? Because he has humbled himself before Me, I will not bring the disaster in his days; but in his son’s days I will bring the disaster upon his house.'
verses.comment: Consequence deferred to next generation, matches original meaning.
